text: Tap. Pours clear pale Amber gold, medium creamy off white head, nice lacing. Aroma is quite hoppy, pine, pot, herbal, field grass. Flavor is light plus sweet, light plus bitter, saison like, grassy and herbal. Medium creamy body.

12oz bottle 6/22/14 (Judicious Spirits Singles)-48° in Mug-Pours a medium golden with a small white head. Aroma of malt, grains, and hops. Taste of the same with more malt. This medium bodied brew is not bad but just not my favorite style.

Enjoyed at Total Wines summer beer tasting class. Nice mild malt aroma. Nice flavor. Mildly effervescent mouth feel. Full body, creamy texture. Good after-taste. One of the better ones in this style.
Decent recreation of the style. Loud enough without being weak, but weak enough that its not as full as it could be.

Sun Devil Liquor bottle. Pours a nice golden color with active carbonation but just a thin white head. Sweet aroma of malt and corn with a hint of alcohol. Flavor is strange, it starts sweet and then ends almost tart/sour. Not really a style Im familiar with but this seemed a little strange.

Rich, malty aromas from a crystal clear light copper body with a fleeting white head. Caramel and light butterscotch jump out with raisins and plums following. That distinctive German lager taste and creaminess comes through along with a dry, leafy bitterness and a good alcohol bite. It all wraps up into a delicious, sweet, herbaceous and warming finish. I think even the Germans would agree this is an excellent Maibock.

Appearance: Slightly hazy orange/gold with a decent off white head.
Aroma: Sweet malt, fruity.
Flavor: Malt, alcohol, somewhat harsh finish.
Palate: Medium to full bodied, mild to moderate carbonation.
Overall: great aroma, with some nice malt characteristics, but uneven.

Clear bright orange pour with a white head. Sweet caramel malt, some candy/sugar, lemon peel, and a bit of yeast. A nice fruity ester aroma, some bread, and a bit of yeast. Theres a lot of apple, lemon peel, and sugar sweetness on the palate. A bit of bread, some yeast, and toasted malt. A bit too sweet for my tastes.

12-oz long neck bottle. 
Pours a nice golden-amber color with a moderate head. 
Pleasant aromas of malts and hops with an additional perfumy scents. 
Sweetness comes first on the palate, immediately balanced by a bitter finish. slightly creamy and overall satisfying. True to type.

I love this beer and can never have enough of it. While I have yet to try Sudwerk's Doppelboch, this one rates as my favorite right now. A nice gold appearance and a wonderful mouth feel, my only complaint is the dry mouth after a enjoying the swallow of this fine beer. If you are lucky enough to find this in your beer aisle, don't pass it by. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Location: 12 oz bottle from Colonial Wine and Spirits, 3/27/12


Aroma: A rather sweet nose, malts, some apple, bread, and some sort candied sugary sweetness

Appearance: It pours a mostly clear golden color with a small white head and some spotty lacing

Flavor: Taste is heavy sweet, the components are the same as the nose, with a grain/bread finish

Palate: The body is medium, it has a slightly cloying, smooth feel, and just a hint of heat on the finish

Overall Impression: 
I didnt love this one.  They were a little heavy handed with the sweetness for my taste, and there was something fake sugary about the feel that also took away from it for me.  Overall, this wasnt terrible, but it certainly wasnt for me.

This beer pours a clear amber with a white head with yellow highlights. Nice lacing rings as the head recedes. Good retention. Nose of sweet caramel malts and some fruit. Medium in body and with a smooth clean mouthfeel. The flavor is good, with some fruit and malt. Nice clean finish. Very drinkable brew with good balance.
Pours clear, hazel nut brown, very nutty easy drinking Bock beer.  Not boozy at all considering its high alcohol percentage, very light hop character.  Over-all, very impressed with this beer.

First tasted @ West coast brew fest. I liked it so I got a six pack @ nugget on sale. Pours amber colour, with a thin white head, and thin lacing. Aromas of lagers never impress me. Flavour is nice and hoppy, which is how I love em. Palate is full bodied, with a thick, dry, sticky finish. Overall a nice beer (for a lager) that hides its high ABV well.

Tap.  Pours clear gold with a small, fizzy white head, short retention with fair lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (biscuit, meal, cereal), light hops (earthy) and clean lager character.  Flavor is heavy malt with supporting hop bitterness and clean lager notes.  Medium body, warmth, and carbonation with a sweet finish.
On tap at West Coast Brewfest 2011. Pours clear blonde with a modest off-white head and a floral fruity aroma. There is a light and refreshing pale malt flavor with slight hop bitterness.

22 oz. bottle from Hayduke with whom it was shared with Rick via Facebook chat.  This beer pours like iced tea with the light brown and clear appearance.  A two finger light yellow golden head slowly fades.  The nose is very inviting with honey, tangerine, and nice malt.  The flavor is quite tasty.  With all due respect to the previous raters, how is this rated 3.3?  Very nice tangerine and more complex fruit, an occasional whiff of alcohol, and a nice caramel malt backbone.  Not overly complex but rock solid and beautifully balanced.  This is really nice!  Thanks Ron.
Clear golden color/ white head. Light berry fruit, sweetbread, yeasty grainy aromas. medium bodied. Decent sweet Hawaiian bread flavors with yeast, mineral.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: UPDATED: OCT 3, 2014 just missed this on tap in the spring, but got a bottle this fall.  label says best for 90 days after bottling date, then gives no bottling date.  nice.  anyway - i had my doubts about this one.  it had escaped the box and had been in the back seat floor of my car for over a week (from 40 degree nights to a couple 90 degree days).  no exploding bottle, and the first whiff didnt tell me it had gone bad.  as it was, this is a fine beer.  nothing great, but definitely not spoiled, with a fruity sweetness and fine balance.  i will try a fresher one and re-rate sooner or later, but i liked this one just fine.

On tap. Pours with a clear orange body with a tan ring. Aroma is toasty and caramel. Taste is diacetyl, caramel and candy corn. Some flavors that remind me of milk. Light bubbles. Not as good as most of Sudwerks German style offerings.

One of the sweetest, full body beers Ive had that somewhat fall under lager.  Muted, but present and tasty hops, go with a sweet malt and is mostly devoid of lagers metal and other less good characters.   A well made beer.

Bottle; first beer from Sudwerk under their own label.  Poured a vibrant orange/amber color with an off white head.  Aroma of sweet malt, caramel, bread, and some lightly toasted elements.  A bit of earthy hopping in the finish too, but not much.  Flavor was less sweet than expected.  More hoppy, with a lot of earthiness in the finish.  Alcohol is about as present as youd expect.  Some light grassy notes.  Malty backbone is always present, but not as assertive as many in the style.  A pretty solid brew, and unexpected in a few ways.

A golden bock with a thick white head. In aroma, a light malt, rather sweet, with light fruity esters. In mouth, fruity malts, light esters of bananas, mineral notes. Medium bodied. On tap at brewpub, August 27 2009.
Bottle 35,5 cl. Clear golden with a dense off-white head. Intensely sweet malty nose. Solid body with sweetish malt and a little sulphur. Subdued bitterness. 100709
12 fl oz bottle. Pours clear and golden orange with a small white head. Sweet and light malty aroma. Sweet malty and light fruity hops flavoured. Mild bitter and cornish to malty flavoured finish.

Bottled. A pale golden beer with an off-white head. The is sweet malty with metallic notes of alcohol. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, and some alcohol, leading to a lightly bitter and lightly alcoholic finish.
Poured orange amber, simple, sweet malts, bready, little hops, little caramel.

Light yellow pour.  Minimal to no head, very light carbination.  Basic taste combo of malt & barley, kinda taste like a pale ale, but I guess it’s supposed to be a lager.  Very bitter aftertaste, very malty.  Not really my thing.

12oz bottle.   Pours a clear vivid gold color with a fluffy white head that leaves a thin layer of foam.   My first impression of the aroma is lots of spicy noble hops, with a light citrus undertone.   Then I get a nice malty honey and doughy yeast aroma as well.   The flavor is malty with a little sweetness at first, and then finishes with a powerful hop spice and long bitter finish.   Simple, clean malt flavors, with a touch of alcohol hotness.   This takes the balance and drinkability of a good pils and takes it up a couple notches.   The super clean malt flavors avoid the sticky, cloying sweetness that can happen in the style, but there is still a substantial enough body to let you know you are drinking a stronger beer.
The nose is mostly banana.  The flavor is dry with some light sweetness hidden in the fold.  It pours clear and very pale.

Thanks for DarkElf for the recommendation!  Golden, bright and sparkling.  Big malt nose is very clean.  Fat malty, bready palate is clean and rich.  A little bit of dryness makes this "moreish", to steal a phrase from Jackson.  Very good.

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2008 On tap at the 2008 Boonville Beer Festival and in bottles.  This is a good, crisp, very tasty maibock with a slightly more pronounced hoppy bite than I usually expect.  

It is light copper gold with a dense, creamy, off-white head steadily shrinking to a thin head.  The smell is raisiny with fruity grain and some hops, honey, bread dough, hay, a bit alcoholic, but smoothly so.  The tatse is similar, sweetish, but with a light spicey bitterness and bite, fruity, zesty, a creamy feel and grassy-herbal bitterness with a hint of apple peel.  Overall, it is clean and  crisp yet very tasty.
350 ml bottle from Bevmo.  Light copper brown with a fizzy head.  Faint malty aroma and taste with a clean finish.

12 oz. glass bottle- color of dark gold, with a minimal off white head - nose of vegetation, crackers(wheat), and sweet  taste of bright red fruit, sweat, sour cherries, and mild hops - body is light, and with medium to light carbonation  aftertaste of sour cherries, and ruby red grapefruit

Bottle Date of 03.22.07, Sampled September 2007
This beer sits in my glass with a brilliantly clear, pretty, copper color, when held up to the light it shows an orange tinged, gold color.  The head starts out almost three-fingers in height and is a pale tan color.  The aroma has a nice grain character to it up front and is finished with some lightly herbal hop notes mixed in.  Aromatic notes of biscuits, sweet honey-like grain, hints of orange flower nectar, lightly caramelized bread crust, and a green, herbaceous note intermingle in the nose, with none really being dominant.

Lightly sweet, but with an immediately noticeable, slightly astringent, bitterness.  The beer finishes with a doughy malt character as well as some caramelized grain sugar notes.  Uncharacteristically these notes seem to linger more than the bitterness that was found mostly up front in this beer.  Fairly thick and rich, though the lightly zesty carbonation helps to temper this a bit.  Some touches of honey character as well as a minty hop note in the finish.

This is quite tasty and I really like the touch with the noticeable hop character; it is perhaps a touch more than traditional German examples, but it is a welcome addition.  I have always welcomed the hoppy pale bocks (something I really consider this "new" Double Pilsner thing to be a part of).  This beer is quite easy to drink, in some ways I wish it had a bit more character, but it seems to want to be quaffed by the liter, which would be quite dangerous.
(Bottle)  Pours a clear golden body with a small white head.  Aroma of florals, cereal, sweet apple, and grass.  Flavor of honey, butter, pear, and dough with a sticky mouthfeel.

Date: 06/02/2005
Mode: Bottle
Source: Tasting

clear light amber, light sweet malt aroma, solid malt flavor well balanced between a touch of sweetness and a short bitter finish, tasty but nothing special

Aroma: 5/10; Appearance: 5/10; Flavor: 5/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 10/20
Rating: 2.6/5.0Score: *4
-------- />
The score was calculated based upon the notes and an old scoring system.

Gold amber pour with lasting white head.  Lagery, yeast malt smell and taste.  Smooth nice lager tyhpe beer with a yeast flavor that Im not crazy about.  
@ City Beer Store in SF

Another fine beer from Sudwerks. These guys really are underrated and so far everything Ive had from them has been above average. Aroma was roasty grains, sweet and slightly fruity. Appearance was light brown, clear with a nice one-finger off white head. Mouthfeel was light. Flavor was malty sweet and slightly roasted. Not a lot of complexity going on here, but thats okay. Its a fine Maibock and just rhe right time for one too.

Aroma of malt, maybe backed by hop; alcohol seems present. Orangy gold color (not my idea of copper) with a white head that leaves. Medium mouthfeel. Definite start of sweet malt, and it is malt with character. Moves on with a bit of spice, leaves the mouth a bit atingle. The malt tends to stay on into the finish, and there is not really enough hop to balance this. Pretty good. One of the better lagers Ive had in some time.

On tap at the brewpub in October.  .3L pour.  Faint, metallic, vegetable-like aroma with some sweet honey-like notes.  Aroma is less than par per style.  Transparent, orangey-copper colored body with a small, lightly off-yellowish head.  Spiced, hoppy start which turns a bit sweet in the middle.  Metallic hops present later in the finish.  Smooth, drinkable, and well-done for a maibock.  I wish the aroma was more aggressive.

Pours copper just like the commercial description says.  Very malty and gives you a feeling as if the beer is coarsing through your veins with excitement at every turn.  It was a good brew, probably still is.

Bottle pours a light golden with a large white head that had amazing lasting power.   Spotty lacing.  Light malts that are a bit paler than I expectedfrom a Bock.  Flavor was light and a bit sweet, lacking some of the darker notes I expected.  Body was medium, softly carbonated and a pleasant finish.
Smells funny; cant place it. This is a pretty decent beer. Tasty malts with some nice hops. Definitely worth trying.

Bottle: Pours a golden color with a bit of head, average head and lacing. The nose is lightly sweet with some typical pale malts and light alcohol, some clean pear fruitiness and light hops. The flavor has a nice body with some clean sweet malts. Finishes balanced, decent.

(Bottle from World Market Sampler) Nose is caramel malts, with a little sweetness; Copper colored with a tiny off-white head; Caramelly malt flavor with a tiny bit of tartness (very slight) and a nice hop finish.

Thanks to droopy49 for sending this one!
Large, long lasting, off white head over a medium gold colored body.
Good malt aroma with some spicy honey notes.
Smooth, malty and well balanced as it should be. Nice beer!

Delicious body of malty love.  For an example of clean lager characteristics and smooth maltiness, try this beer.  A fine sweet grain flavor dominates this one.  Just a tiny tingle of hop on the finish.  Right beer for cool Southern California evenings and bonfires.

Aroma: Caramel and Malty aroma with a little herbal
Appearance: Nice Golden Orangy... with a thin white head which dissipates quickly
Flavor: Solidly malty with nice bready and honey flavors with the sweetness kept in check with nice bitterness:
Palate: Medium bodied carbonation, feels a little prickly Starts with malty sweetness which is replaced with hoppy bitterness in the finish
Overall: A very good beer, but I would have hoped for a little more presence in the nose and a drier finish

Bottle:  Courtesy of DarkElf via trade.  Second beer Ive had that I notice a strong pet store odor which is not pleasant.  Behind that lies some toffee, roasted grain, and fruit.  I find these underlying aromas nice, but just cant get past the pet store odor.  Pours a slightly hazy golden-orange with a moderate white head that diminishes rather quickly.   Taste is much better than the aroma.  Lots of sweet caramel from start to finish.  Very light hints of fruit and grain.  Slightest hints of bitterness in the finish.  Very tastey and I really enjoyed the beer overall, but the aroma score is really going to put a ding in my total score.

On tap at the brewpub. Has the exact same appearance as the helles- dark gold with a white head. Odd aromatic floral aroma. The flavor is the remarkable thing here. An astringently medicinal potion whose floral sweetness is strong. The chemical medicine flavor dominates. What is it? Odd, but I strangely like it.

Bottle: Hazy pale golden, moderate fizzy head, spotty lacing, very little carbonation.   Rich bready nose, biscuity, grainy, and malty.   Quite grainy on the tongue, semi-sweet, with a thick malty finish.   Pretty straight forward.   The raw graininess somewhat detracts, but otherwise its a fairly clean beer.   7.3% ABV is well hidden.   Average body and mouthfeel.   Finishes fairly simple, semi-sweet maltiness, otherwise nothing out of the ordinary.   Somewhat heavy on the graininess, which I dont much care for.   Fairly decent.   Thanks Stephen!

Fruity, herbal, bready aroma.  Clear golden body is topped by a lasting, fine bubbled, white head.  Slightly boozy, fruity, herbal flavour with plenty of yeast characteristics and fair finishing bitterness.  Medium body with fair carbonation and strong alcohol warming.  Sampled at GABF 2005.

12 oz bottle as a bonus in a trade with DarkElf - Thanks Stephen!  Pours golden with a short white head that fades quickly.  Aroma of dough, honey, and some hay.  Flavor is malty.  Notes of bread, honey, something sweet too.  Palate is crisp clean and smooth.  Finished with grassy hops.  Carbonated about right.  Drinkable but nothing memorable.  Fair for the style though.

Bottle poured a clear golden amber with a lasting white head. Aromas of biscuits, honey, and a bit of herbal character. Palate was clean and crisp. Flavors of sweet honey biscuits,a bit of citrus and has a sweet finish.

Large white head lasts over the clean golden shade. Very perfumey and apparently artificially sweetened nose strikes with Pillsbury dough flavours, strongly reminiscent of honeyed biscuits, cotton candy, just something too sweet to be true. Fruity esters are lost among the candy land, the overbearing sweetness mostly keeps on in mouth, despite growing bitterness that doesnt manage to translate into any notable aromatics besides dull tart herbs. Light-medium bodied, soft carbonation, soooo biscuity, too much for me to handle and convincing me to keep on my streak of staying away from Mr. Christie.

orangey-golden clear body with lots of fizz.  fluffy merangue-like rocky white head.  grassy yeasty aroma, also toffee malt.  high carbonation.  flavor is corn pops and banana, spicy malt, and a sour grassy bite in the finish.  dry aftertaste.  these are all enjoyable things to me, and I agree this is a great example of its class.  thanks for this great bonus beer, DarkElf!!
09.30.05 GABF  Pale golden.  Tuti-fruit nose and sweetened breakfast cereal.  Very hoppy, floral.  Complex layers of sweetness with caramel, blossom, honey.  Nice stuff.

(Draft: Sudwerk Restaurant and Brewery in Davis, CA) Ive had this in bottles many times, and its one of my favorite Sudwerk beers, but I figured since I was at the brewery, Id try it on tap.  Just as tasty as ever.  Sweet, caramely, malty nose with a lager feel to it, just like what a good Maibock should smell like.  The sweet, caramel is alive in the flavor, dominating all else.  Very gently bitter, the balance is very much tilted toward the malty end.  Mild alcohol seems to come out in the finish.  Full bodied, sweet, rich, and fairly sticky on the long-lasting palate.  Bright amber in color and fully clear of course, with a sizeable, off-white head to start.  As the head fades to a small halo, it leaves a few wide, intricate rings at the top of the glass.  Just an excellent Maibock, probably as good as any Ive had in this country, either domestic or imported.

Clear golden body with moderate carbonation, some discernible viscosity, and a slow-fading, uniform, sudsy white head that completely faded. Aroma of mild pale malt and a note of alcohol. Light apple in the flavor plus rich pale malt, honey notes, and delicate spicy hops. Comes across medium sweet with mild, tangy acidity, light bitterness, and noticeable strength. Sweet character builds but never becomes cloying. This is a decent strong lager. Thanks DarkElf.

Pours a clear copper golden with a thin fixxy white head.  Aroma of rich grainy caramel malt and a nice lager yeasty profile.  Body starts sweet and thick with some noble hoppy bitterness and a slightly sticky warming finish.  Nicely balanced and fairly complex, a good maibock.  Thanks beeryum!

Bottle.  Pours clear amber, with a nice sweet malty nose.  Nice malty flavor, with some soft fruit hint, apple or maybe pear.  I agree with some of the other reviews, that the body is a nice medium, but it does seem a bit grainy.  Overall, a very nice bock.
Poured a golden yellow.  Aroma was sweet malty with a background of apples.  Very sweet malty, caramel and a bitter finish.  Medium to full body.

UPDATED: APR 27, 2005 Bottled 03/04/04. Pours a red color with traces of orange. Sweet and malty is the best way to describe the aroma of this bock. Very thick mouthfeel. Very malty rich flavor. Some roasted qualities. Some sweetness. Trace of hops and maybe a little bit of alcohol. Lots of flavor. Beer is over a year old and still tastes good. Good stuff.
bought this beer because I could not get my hands on Sierra Nevada Pale Bock (a Mai Bock) wish I handt. Too sweet, bad aftertaste.
Honey dew melons and herbs with some lite honey and hop notes. pleasing very german maiboch reminiscent of the Hof-Brauhaus.  great mouthfeel clean finish beautiful beer.

Given as a freebie from DarkElf, thanks! Pours clear amber/gold with a medium white head. Nice aroma of floral hops, graininess and grass. Flavor is pretty sweet and malty. Grainy, grassy and herbal along with caramel, floral hops and some light fruitiness. Moderately bitter aftertaste, a hint of alcohol detected in the finish as it warms. Medium body with a very smooth mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Overall, very nice stuff!

Thanks to DarkElf for this bottle. This is a really nice smooth bock. Pours an orange/amber with a fast falling white head. Lots of sweet malts in the aroma, toasty, caramel, and a touch of hops. Taste is clean and smooth, coating the palate with a rich caramel presence. This finishes with a bold hop edge, very well balance, evening out some of the syrupy sweetness.

Bottle. Thanks to Stephen (DarkElf) for thsi stuff. What an aroma. I love the smell of roasted grains and baby they are all over this. Nice, lasting almost white head. Nice malty taste. There is jus a touch of aluminum going on but the sweetness just about covers it up. Nice flavor.

Sandy auburn, delicate head. Aroma is fresh herbs and shredded salad--zesty and earthy. A little bit of baseline sweetness contributed by the malts. Flavor is initially sweet, any sugariness is propelled away by a nice bitting hoppy dryness and a smidgeon of tasteful EtOH. This is a nice one. The sixer says 16.5 Plato OG, which Im guessing translates to about 6.5% ABV. A good lighter bock.

Medium gold color. Small white foamy head. Aroma is fruity and sweet. A medium bodied bock. Malts are fruity and very sweet, caramel and malts. Hops are slightly spicy. Nicely balanced, big bold bock. Alcohol is very evident and the alcohol oiliness is very noticeable. Nicely balanced. Smooth taste. Hints of wood and smoke in the middle, Finishing crisp and biting. Nice beer. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and crisp. Aftertaste is slightly bitter
Tap at Brewery. This is big maltly but clean tasting beer with a big malt syrup/caramel aftertaste. Easy drinking for so much alcohol.

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2004 
The beer upon its release from the 12-ounce brown bottles set in the glass a slightly hazy amber color with a moderate in size bright white head the is semi-creamy in texture and as it evaporates the lace formed is a fine sealing sheet. Nose is malt laden, sweet, quite crisp and clean with the start lightly sweet and nicely malted with the top light. Finish is stern in its acidity and the hops delectable in their spiciness, very dry aftertaste and a nice drinking beer.
